title: Darren Lewis: Huge charity money mountain needs to go to needy veterans
text:

With Poppy Day approaching, most of us won’t think twice about donating for the fallen.

Nor do people have any problem with supporting the many veterans struggling with mental health or having fallen on hard times.

What will stun members of the public approached by those rattling tins over the next week or so is the revelation that Britain’s ten biggest military charities already have combined assets of over £1.4billion - with reserves of nearly £280million. Money just sitting there, catching dust.

The amounts are jaw-dropping when you consider that up to 3% of people sleeping rough in England are ex-servicemen and women.

Around 3,500 homeless veterans across the UK are not getting the support they are entitled to. A number that that cash could easily wipe out.

(Image: Daily Post Wales)

According to figures compiled by Plaid Cymru last year, more than 60,000 armed forces veterans in the UK have either broken the law, found themselves homeless or are suffering from mental health issues.

The stats suggest 10,000 are in prison, on parole or on probation having turned to crime.

So for the military charities to have the equivalent of the money pile in the TV series Breaking Bad sitting in a vault somewhere, doing nothing, is a disgrace.

The Mirror’s Pride of Britain Awards are in their 20th year of celebrating veterans as well as everyday people whose acts of bravery and selflessness were an inspiration to us all.

There are so many worthy charities working hard to alleviate the suffering of men and women unable to help themselves physically, practically and emotionally.

(Image: TIM ANDERSON)

It is a scandal that they are not backed by the finances that could change lives. Especially when so many are bracing themselves for yet another cold winter on the streets.

It is no good Edward Parker, Chief Executive for the Walking With The Wounded charity, calling for more to be done to help those in need to access services. The money is there to get out on the streets and take the help to them.

People want to keep giving to back up the work of those on the front line. What they could grow tired of doing is topping up a money mountain while the people who need it most suffer.
